body:
Okay, I've reconciled my working branch with this one, restoring a few additional removed APIs since 1.9, and cleaning up some other stuff, including slight rewording of deprecated javadoc messages.

Tests are broken still, and there may be some opportunity to clean up deprecation warnings from the compiler. I'll work on those issues to wrap this up.

@cjmctague what do you mean by `that are not automated` in your commit message?  Does that refer to these not being automatically done in the maven build?  What tool did you use to make these changes?

@keith-turner Yes, that they are not checked during the maven build with the formatter or the checkstyles. Intellij said there were about 650ish instances of the constant being on the left and 6500ish of them being on the right in comparisons. So I had it refactor the 650 instances to match the rest of the project.
I will look at this now.
All ITs ran successfully for this change.
Currently ConfigurationTypeHandler will only warn if a class can't be loaded, which is the same it does for the crypto service.

I did some research and found the tablet server code that is causing this.  Every time a write ahead log is created it is [immediately added to zookeeper](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.2/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/log/TabletServerLogger.java#L286).  When writing to a walog if any error occurs then the [WAL is closed](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.2/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/log/TabletServerLogger.java#L455).  Sometimes the exceptions that occur are unrelated to writing to the walog and occur before anything was ever written to the walog.  If the error keeps happening then this ends up adding lots of empty walogs to ZK which are used during recovery.

One possible solution is that when a walog is closed if nothing was written to it then mark the walog in ZK in such a way that is GCed.  Could possibly immediately remove the file after marking it in ZK.  If the process dies between ZK and delete, then the Accumulo GC would still clean it up.

Was able to test the crypto and I think these changes are good.  @PircDef feel free to weigh in but I think I figured out that we always want the NoFlushOutputstream and in this case it is fair to not push it up into the crypto implementation.
FWIW I agree with not pushing it into the crypto implementation

> This is neat. How did you find this?

The commit method was one that was showing up a lot using flight recorder so this lead me to dive down to calls in it and noticed that value was counted twice.
Ran the ITs here https://jenkins.revelc.net/job/Accumulo-PR/122/
All ITs passed for this PR.
Reverted the commit that touched the new API.  Then reran the code inspection to see what else is now unused.
@mikewalch or @keith-turner you guys OK with the rest of the changes?

@ctubbsii thanks for taking a look at this.  This was more of an experiment using Intellij Run Inspection by name but it became too cumbersome with our API and pluggable interfaces.  I plan on using a more focused approach for removing unused code next time.

@milleruntime I thought this worked out fine. It caught some stuff we maybe didn't want removed... but I think we caught all those in the reviews. Even if we didn't, the risk was minimal, since none of it touched the public API.
Eventually, all our "internal pluggable" stuff should be in declared SPI packages, to make it easier to ensure stability. We're still stuck with the historical stuff for now, though.
Does this supersede #850 ?

> Does this supersede #850 ?

It looks like it might.
@milleruntime, oops! I didn't see your PR when I made this. However, I do think the check should be in SiteConfiguration.  Feel free to update your PR and we can merge yours.  Sorry about that.
I will work on this.
Superseded by #852 which adds the check back to SiteConfiguration, where it was previously.

> @milleruntime, oops! I didn't see your PR when I made this. However, I do think the check should be in SiteConfiguration. Feel free to update your PR and we can merge yours. Sorry about that.

No worries!  I closed mine since yours is what we want.  I will test the crypto issue once you merge to make sure that also gets fixed.
Fixed in #852
This PR will fix https://github.com/apache/fluo-uno/issues/210

Fired off another run of the ITs: https://jenkins.revelc.net/job/Accumulo-PR/123/
Ideally the changes related to #807 would be in separate commits which are in another branch and PR.
ITs running here: https://jenkins.revelc.net/job/Accumulo-PR/124/
was this fixed in 1.9 also? or is 1.9 unaffected?

@ctubbsii, the code is different in 1.9 so I didn't think so. However, I just tested 1.9 and this does occur in 1.9 too.  While I think the current directory shouldn't be put on CLASSPATH, some users may be expecting it so I am 50/50 on whether this should be fixed in 1.9. I am going to put up a PR for 1.9 and see what everyone thinks.

> we cannot simply read the file and store the credentials in the job configuration. That defeats the whole point of having the feature to use a token file.

I agree. I think the only way to fix this in the old API is to revert how we serialize the client properties. 

How do you propose handling the token file in the new API?

> I agree. I think the only way to fix this in the old API is to revert how we serialize the client properties.

I think that's best.

> How do you propose handling the token file in the new API?

In the new API, we do not need to have a "Token File" feature at all. We already support serializing credentials into a client properties file. We just need to make sure that if a user sets the client properties file (vs. setting a token directly in the fluent API), we do not immediately read that file and store its contents as properties in the job. We should handle it either by putting the file in the distributed cache, or simply serialize the path to the file around so we can read it from HDFS directly in the input/output formats. This would basically mean protecting the contents of the client properties file in the new API the same way we treated the token file in the old API.

I find it weird that an empty CLASSPATH item would be interpreted as "current directory", instead of requiring an explicit dot (.) for that. That seems like a bug to me. Is this documented as intended behavior by the JVM or is this behavior that is specific to what we're doing?

I agree that current directory shouldn't be automatically put on the class path with an empty path element... but not sure I understand why it's happening. We can continue the conversation on the other PR (#864)

Reverting the old MR code back to using Connector becomes a problem down in the implementation in getSplits().  Because of other improvements in 2.0, we now need a ClientContext aka Client to create an OfflineScanner, Tablet Location and other places.  We have no a way to create a ClientContext or AccumuloClient without client properties.
OK maybe it will work with ClientConfConverter... let me try.
Another run after fix: https://jenkins.revelc.net/job/Accumulo-PR/125/
I think the ITs are still failing.
ConnectorImpl contains a ClientContext instance we can use.

I have been looking into this and I think it could only happen if the GC pulled info about an unreferenced WAL into memory before a tserver died AND then deleted the unreferenced WAL after the tserver died (while the master is trying to get the list).  The GC seems to completely ignore WALs for any dead tservers that have tablets assigned to them.
Looking at the history of WalStateManager it seems like this may have been a bug since 1.8.0.

Pardon my ignorance: do we differentiate properties that can be changed dynamically and those which require a restart? That's my biggest concern -- I think your change would require a config-change+restart instead of just at config-change that we have now.

> Pardon my ignorance: do we differentiate properties that can be changed dynamically and those which require a restart?

In the past, I don't think we've done a good job at this differentiation. I think there's a natural differentiation, which we could use: properties which can be set in ZooKeeper, and those that can't, but even those that can be set in ZooKeeper, there's not well-defined behavior as to when they will go into effect. This is something that we should think about doing better in future. That's outside the scope of this issue, in the general case, but in this narrow case, I think Josh makes a good point: if you can change the configuration for a replication receiver on a running system, we should probably make sure that the services respond to that configuration change... and we can't do that if they are disabled on startup and don't monitor for configuration changes to re-enable.

> if you can change the configuration for a replication receiver on a running system, we should probably make sure that the services respond to that configuration change... and we can't do that if they are disabled on startup and don't monitor for configuration changes to re-enable.

Yes, this was half of my point. The other half is that we need to have documentation that would tell people that they need to restart Accumulo after making this change, especially since this changes previous semantics. Probably release notes to advertise the immediate change and user manual to tell people for the future that they need to do it.

It looks like there's a "fixed Zoo property" concept, which we label on some properties, which indicates things that can be changed in ZK, but won't be recognized until restart of some service/daemon... not sure if that is used in the generated docs for properties... but it seems like it easily could be. (EDIT: turns out "fixed properties" already indicate the need to restart to take effect, so we can just ensure it's properly marked as a "fixed property".)
:+1: Need to do a similar thing to the 1.9 branch. :)

Yeah a fixed property will get a little snippet in the generated doc like `gc.port.client` does here:
"zk mutable: yes but requires restart of the gc"
With this change, we could throw an illegal state exception if the user sets a property on the fly, expecting data to get replicated.  I am not sure where that would be done though.

It's easy to make `replication.name` a [fixed property](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/90dfad3b341a5098113ea8fdce28a0bc4511d067/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/conf/Property.java#L1189) but it looks like [this method](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/ce1aa1f76577caed521f9668147f1ca81239b137/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/conf/ConfigurationDocGen.java#L135) will need to updated for the docs to say Accumulo needs to be restarted (as right now it will say replication needs to be restarted.)

> It's easy to make replication.name a fixed property but it looks like this method will need to updated for the docs to say Accumulo needs to be restarted (as right now it will say replication needs to be restarted.)

This makes me wonder if the REPLICATION prefix properties should all be TSERVER.  The names would be longer but seems more accurate to me.

> This makes me wonder if the REPLICATION prefix properties should all be TSERVER. The names would be longer but seems more accurate to me.

If it affects the remote replication receiver service built in to the tserver to act as a destination for replicas, then probably.

> This makes me wonder if the REPLICATION prefix properties should all be TSERVER. The names would be longer but seems more accurate to me.

I am not too familiar with replication but it's properties might be used in tserver and master.  I think the documentation should not call out the process to be restarted by using the prefix of the property.  Either we should make sure that this prefix is an Accumulo process (i.e master, tserver, monitor, etc) or just have a general message in the docs like `zk mutable: yes but requires a restart`. Users can determine which processes should be restarted.

> I am not too familiar with replication but it's properties might be used in tserver and master.

That's correct. There's logic across master and tabletserver for replication. The intent to have its own prefix was to keep all replication configuration in "one place".

> just have a general message in the docs like zk mutable: yes but requires a restart

+1

> With this change, we could throw an illegal state exception if the user sets a property on the fly, expecting data to get replicated. I am not sure where that would be done though.

That would be client side validation, right? I suppose it's not unreasonable for this case to let client-side validation be sufficient (e.g. it's not bad if a user circumvents our own code and tries to set a zk-mutable property -- worst case, it's just ineffectual). That sounds like a good idea. Even if not an exception, a WARN would go a long way for operators to realize they straying from the "norm"

We can certainly fix the message without fixing the property names, but if it a configuration knob for tserver, then it should be prefixed accordingly. The convention we have is that properties for specific processes are prefixed with the process type, if they affect all of Accumulo, they are prefixed with either `general.` or `instance.` (the latter being used for instance-identifying information... information that together establishes the an identity for a cluster and must be the same across the entire cluster in order for each component to identify as part of the same Accumulo instance).

> We can certainly fix the message without fixing the property names

Let's do one thing at a time, please. This discussion doesn't belong on a PR about not starting up services in certain situations.

> Let's do one thing at a time, please.

Agreed. My thinking is that there are multiple possible follow-on actions which may affect the decision about the initial action. Have we reached consensus on the initial set of actions here? If so, is it the following?

1. enable/disable replication based on startup config,
2. used fixed properties to document that changes in ZK require restart, and
3. clean up wording of said documentation so it's not based on property name

Or something else?

> > Let's do one thing at a time, please.
> 
> Agreed. My thinking is that there are multiple possible follow-on actions which may affect the decision about the initial action. Have we reached consensus on the initial set of actions here? If so, is it the following?
> 
> 1. enable/disable replication based on startup config,
> 2. used fixed properties to document that changes in ZK require restart, and
> 3. clean up wording of said documentation so it's not based on property name
> 
> Or something else?

I also suggest throwing an error on the client if replication properties are set (through the shell I guess) when the tserver doesn't have a replication.name.  Perhaps this could be done in ConfigSanityCheck and print a warning?

It's not clear to me how all the replication properties work together... which ones are on the send side and which ones affect the receive side.

It might be best to just add a new fixed property (requires restart), `tserver.replicationservices.enabled=true/false` and leave all the replication property stuff for future cleanup/improvements.

> It's not clear to me how all the replication properties work together... which ones are on the send side and which ones affect the receive side.
> 
> It might be best to just add a new fixed property (requires restart), `tserver.replicationservices.enabled=true/false` and leave all the replication property stuff for future cleanup/improvements.

+1  I like this the best.  This also won't require changing the documentation for the other properties since it would get generated to say "zk mutable: yes but requires restart of the tserver".

Could do the following :  
 * If replication.name is set to empty string then don't start up replication related services in the tserver.
 * In the tserver create a timer that checks if replication.name transitions from empty to non-empty then automatically start the services in the tserver.  This is similar to how there are timers that check if thread pool sizes need to be adjusted.

This change should hopefully be transparent to the user.

> Could do the following :
> 
> * If replication.name is set to empty string then don't start up replication related services in the tserver.
> * In the tserver create a timer that checks if replication.name transitions from empty to non-empty then automatically start the services in the tserver.  This is similar to how there are timers that check if thread pool sizes need to be adjusted.
> 
> This change should hopefully be transparent to the user.

Ok I think this would work the best.  And also, the more I thought about it, it doesn't make sense to have a new property (or have a tserver property) so I will go back to how I was checking initially on replication.name.
Pushed new test to my fork: jzeiberg/accumulo
@jzgithub1 Feel free to create a pull request whenever you feel it is ready to contribute to the project. :smiley_cat:

OK I think these changes work best for all use cases and require no action from users.  I made a thread in each Master and tserver that checks every 5 seconds if replication.name is set.  Then if it is set, startup all the services.  That seemed to be a reasonable time to check since any longer, and the tests began failing.  

The only other part in question was whether to kill the threads after starting the services.  I didn't see a graceful way to do that with SimpleTimer though.
OBE'd by cached thread pool
I have attempted to do that but since I already have a pull request on that fork,  Github is preventing me from making additional ones.
While I am happy this is fixed in master & 2.0, I don't think this should be fixed for 1.9 as it could cause problems for user relying on this behavior.

@jzgithub1 I am closing this pull request because it contains change for multiple unrelated things.  I merged the changes you made for #807, so that is done.  I looked into merging the changes for #810 however those changes are not ready and still need work. I have not looked at the changes for  #849,  I can look at those when they are in a separate PR.

In order to create multiple PRs you need to create multiple branches locally, push those branches to your fork, and then create a PR. You should also base your local master branch on upstream apache accumulo.  Below are the commands that I would execute to create multiple PRs AND get your master branch in a good state.  I have not tested these commands.  Let me know if you have any questions.

```bash
# locally make sure you are on your master branch, which seems to be where all of your changes are
git checkout master
# create a branch with a backup of the master commits
git checkout -b master-backup
# esnsure your commit are there
git log
# ensure you are on the master-backup branch
git status

# switch back to the master branch
git checkout master
# add a remote named upstream for apache/accumulo
git remote add upstream https://github.com/apache/accumulo.git
# look at the remotes you have configured
git remote -v
# reset your local master branch to be the same as apache/accumulo master branch
git reset --hard upstream/master
git checkout .
# the following command should show things are clean (no changed files)
git status
# make your local master branch pull change from apache/accumulo master.  Usually you would not 
# commit directly to your local master branch
git branch --set-upstream master upstream/master
# the following command should pull the latest changes from apache/accumulo
git pull
# create a branch called accumulo-810 based on master 
git checkout -b accumulo-810
# patch your changes to MiniAccumuloClusterImpl.java from the master-backup branch.  Only
# accept the changes you made.  Since you forked this file has changed, so you are patching in an older 
# version of the file.  So do not patch in older code that had been changed.
git checkout --patch master-backup minicluster/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/miniclusterImpl/MiniAccumuloClusterImpl.java
# Diff the accumulo-810 branch with master, should only see the changes you made
git diff master
git commit -am "some message"
# The command below assumes origin is the remote for your fork of Accumulo.  It will push your branch.
git push -u origin accumulo-810
# after pushing go to the github website and create a PR

# You need to create another PR for #849.  Below are some commands for that.
# make sure your master branch is up to date
git checkout master
git pull
# create a branch for the PR off of master
git checkout -b accumulo-849
# patch in your changes from the master-backup branch
git checkout --patch master-backup core/src/test/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/client/summary/CountingSummarizerTest.java
# compare diffs with master
git diff master
git commit -am "some message"
# if good, then push and make another PR
git push -u origin accumulo-849

# If you need to make changes to either PR, then checkout that branch, edit, commit, and then push.
# Below is an example of this
git checkout accumulo-810
# edit a file and commit
git commit -am "some message"
git push
# should see the commit on the PR
```

Keith's instructions above are great.  You should also check out the [Contribution Workflow](https://accumulo.apache.org/how-to-contribute/#contribution-workflow) for Accumulo on our How To Contribute page.

That is a link to edit the markdown source for the website and make a pull request to the website.

MultiTserverReplicationIT was failing due to this change (it assumed services were always running) but was easily fixed in 01f89e2.  @joshelser were your concerns resolved with my latest changes?
Taking a look at the latest you have pushed now, @milleruntime .

I would prefer we fix this in 1.9.3 also. It seems like a misconfiguration if a user is relying on an empty classpath element loading something from the current directory. We already support users setting their own CLASSPATH in the scripts, so they can always get that behavior by explicitly adding the current directory themselves if they wish.
All ITs in test/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/test/replication are now passing.
I made thrift changes for this for this PR. I put the changes to automatically generated thrift code in their own commit.
@joshelser let me know if you are happy with the updates I made on this PR and I will merge.
@milleruntime one comment up above on SimpleTimer (if you could double-check that?), then I'm good. Thanks for the review ping.

> one comment up above on SimpleTimer (if you could double-check that?), then I'm good. 

I looked into it a bit and replied to your comment.  I think we are OK.

Hey Jeff it looks like you have more commits on this branch than just your work for #849.  One way to fix this in git, is to do the following:
To get your master straight (assuming upstream is set to gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf/accumulo.git):
- git checkout master
- git reset --hard upstream/master

Then create a new branch with the changes:
- git checkout -b counting-sum-test
- git cherry-pick -n c791880f8d407b0ac511d90c0b83972f44e0b2ed 

Assuming those are the changes you want just for this branch. Add them and commit
- git add .
- git commit

Sorry about that.  I thought I got is correct.  I had a little trouble with the 'git reset --hard upstream/master' command.  I pull the upsteam master into my project and reset to Head to the last commit and followed Keith's other instructions.  It looked good.  I will take your advice.
All ITs in accumulo/test/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/test/replication are still passing
I am finding these changes difficult to follow.  I plan on checking out your branch to look at these changes again tomorrow.

I think these changes are good and definitely needed.  My only concern is the complexity of the LoadFiles FATE transaction.  I think at the very least we need another class to abstract some of the logic, similar to how we have OfflineLoader and OnlineLoader.  We could add something to the Loader abstract class for queueing up load messages.

Another idea would be to break up LoadFiles into multiple FATE steps.  We could have something like QueueFiles and the SendFiles.

> We could add something to the Loader abstract class for queueing up load messages.

 I don't think pushing the logic up makes sense because OfflineLoader does not need this logic.  The queuing behavior is specific to the OnlineLoader.

> Another idea would be to break up LoadFiles into multiple FATE steps. We could have something like QueueFiles and the SendFiles.

Seems like this would require pushing another file to HDFS that is sorted differently, which I don't think would simplify things.

I think the real problem comes with the complexity of the LoadFiles class itself and not these changes.  I can try and come up with some ideas how to make it easier to understand and maintain, separate from this PR.

This is good, because in Java 11, you can't enumerate the runtime class path from the system class loader, because it can't be cast to a URLClassLoader, and all the methods and types to enumerate its runtime settings are private and/or buried in the `java.base` module, which doesn't export the system class loader type's package. So, the best we can get for that is to just look at what the value of `System.getProperty("java.class.path")` or, even simpler, just `echo "$CLASSPATH"` in the script.
Few ITs are failing so I will have to push up some fixes.
Ran full build and all ITs passed.

@mikewalch I made some changes in 7d0a967.  We had been passing a hard coded class to the serialization in the RecordReader and writer but that broke with this PR.  This next change just passes the calling class all the way down to the serialization and doesn't make any assumptions about who is calling getSplits() and initialize().
There's more to fix here, I think, but (SSL M/R tests, for example), but this is the bulk of it. I'll try to wrap up the rest today.
I believe this supersedes #862 ?
I will work on this issue

> I believe this supersedes #862 ?

Yes.

Yes this is better.  The only changes you see in the diff are just the changes for this task.  It looks like you have a duplicate commit of the same thing though.  A quick rebase, dropping one of the commits should fix this:
git rebase -i HEAD~2
-- remove one of the commits.  If using VIM: "dd" one of the commits and then ":wq"

It looks like the commits are different but have the same commit message.  While I would avoid using the same commit message in the future, you don't need to update this PR.  The commits can be squashed into one commit when approved and merged.
Good suggestions, thanks @keith-turner .  You OK with the other changes? Can you take a quick look at the scanTime math in the finish method to make sure I preserved the calculations.
